'''Gamil Zirak''', also called '''Zirak'''<ref>{{LR|P2VI}}, pp. 319, 322</ref> or the '''Old''', was a [[Dwarves|Dwarf]] smith and the master of [[Telchar]] of [[Nogrod]].<ref name=":0">[[J.R.R. Tolkien]], [[Christopher Tolkien]] (ed.), ''[[Unfinished Tales]]'', "Index; *Gamil Zirak"</ref>

== History ==
Gamil Zirak was a Dwarf smith, master of Telchar of Nogrod, maker of many renowned works. Gamil Zirak was a great craftsman himself, and the treasuries of [[Thingol]] were known to hold examples of his work.<ref>{{UT|Narn}}, ''The Departure of Túrin''</ref>

Even though it isn't explicitly stated in the text, the fact that Gamil Zirak was the master of Telchar of Nogrod makes it probable that he also lived in that city.

Whether he lived in Nogrod or its neighboring city [[Belegost]], it's probable that Gamil Zirak was one of the [[Firebeards]] or [[Broadbeams]], the two dwarven houses that settled in the [[Blue Mountains]].<ref>[[J.R.R. Tolkien]], [[Christopher Tolkien]] (ed.), ''[[The Peoples of Middle-earth]]'', Part Two: Late Writings, X. "[[Of Dwarves and Men]]"</ref> It's also probable that, besides [[Khuzdul]], he spoke [[Sindarin]], for that was the custom among the Dwarves.<ref>[[J.R.R. Tolkien]], [[Christopher Tolkien]] (ed.), ''[[The Silmarillion]]'', "[[Quenta Silmarillion]]", 10. "[[Of the Sindar]]"</ref>

== Etymology ==
''[[Gamil]]'' is probably a [[Khuzdul]] word, of unknown meaning. Some people find worthy of noting its striking similarity to [[Old Norse]] ''gamall'' ("old"),<ref>[https://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:text:2003.02.0002:entry=gamall “gamall”], in Geir T. Zoëga, ''A Concise Dictionary of Old Icelandic'', Oxford: Clarendon Press</ref> which quite possibly was the inspiration for the former, since Gamil Zirak was also called "the Old", for it woudn't be the first time a Dwarvish name was taken from Old Norse.<ref group="note">For more, see: [[North Germanic languages]]</ref>

''[[Zirak]]'' is a Khuzdul word meaning "tine"<ref>{{PE|17}}, pp. 35-6</ref> or "spike".<ref>{{TI|VIII}}, pp. 174-5 (note 22)</ref>
